answers.body_markdown:
Your code is absolutely against all the rules of the python code. Should have been written like this:

    text = 'hello'
    for number in range(10) :
        print( number, text )

1. No unneeded initializations for `number`
2. No `while` loop, which often leads to errors

answers.title: Merging strings with "%" in Python

answers.body_markdown:
In `print("%d, %s" % number, text)` statement, you need to provide a tuple of parameters to the string formatting (in your case "%d, %s"). So, the correct way to do this is -

    print("%d, %s" % (number, text))

or 

    print number, text  # applicable for python 2.7
    # print (number, text) # Python 3. Python 2.7 prints a tuple

The second one is applicable as you are not printing anything other that the variables.
For the first one you need a tuple for where you are providing more than one arguments during string formatting. So, if want to print say only number, you can do just `print ("%d" %number)` or `print "%d" %number`. The tuple in this case is not mandatory, but you can always do `print ("%d" %(number,))` if you really want to type some more characters.

But the first one is old way of doing things. For newer and more cooler version, use `format()` like below -

    print("{}, {} blah blah blah".format(number, text))

or,

    print "{}, {} blah blah blah".format(number, text)

For more info, check out - https://docs.python.org/2/library/string.html#format-string-syntax

Also follow the answer given by @lenik for other problems in your code.
answers.title: Merging strings with "%" in Python

answers.body_markdown:
[`Json_Contains()`][1] expects the Second argument to be a valid JSON Document, while you are passing a string. 

> An error occurs if target or candidate is not a valid JSON document

Use `'["us"]'` instead of `"us"`. [View on DB Fiddle](https://www.db-fiddle.com/f/ryjt7nvRgS1zjYv2D4AShD/0):

    SET @jsn := '{"language":["en","fr"],"country":["us"]}';

    SELECT JSON_CONTAINS(@jsn, '["us"]', '$.country');

    | JSON_CONTAINS(@jsn, '["us"]', '$.country') |
    | ------------------------------------------ |
    | 1                                          |


But then, if I understand correctly, you are trying to find those JSON doc wherein the array corresponding to `country` key contains `'us'`. `JSON_CONTAINS()` cannot be used to achieve this directly. You will need to use a combination of [`JSON_EXTRACT()`][2] and [`JSON_SEARCH()`][3]. Note that you are only looking for a match, so second argument can be `one` in `Json_Search()` function: 

    SET @jsn := '{"language":["en","fr"],"country":["us"]}';

    SELECT 
      JSON_SEARCH(JSON_EXTRACT(@jsn, '$.country'), 'one', 'us');

    | JSON_SEARCH(JSON_EXTRACT(@jsn, '$.country'), 'one', 'us') |
    | --------------------------------------------------------- |
    | "$[0]"                                                    |

[View on DB Fiddle](https://www.db-fiddle.com/f/ryjt7nvRgS1zjYv2D4AShD/2)


Now, `Json_Search` returns NULL if any of the json_doc, search_str, or path arguments are NULL; no path exists within the document; or search_str is not found. So, you will need to use `IS NOT NULL` in your `WHERE` clause. Use the following query instead:
```
SELECT user_id 
FROM user 
WHERE JSON_SEARCH(JSON_EXTRACT(user_info, '$.country'), 'one', 'us') IS NOT NULL
```


  [1]: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/json-search-functions.html#function_json-contains
  [2]: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/json-search-functions.html#function_json-extract
  [3]: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/json-search-functions.html#function_json-search

> create the code of a CRUD

### No!

But if you want the CRUD methods copied from a properly defined stub use
```shell
php artisan make:controller EntityController -r
```
where the `-r` flag means a resourceful controller for the model `Entity` with `create`, `show`, `index`, `store`, `update`, `edit`, and `delete` methods

The methods uses the proper parameters and apply convenient Dependency Injection and are named according to
```php
Route::resource('Entity', 'EntityController');
```
However you must write your own implementation
answers.title: Laravel - Create automated CRUD?

answers.body_markdown:
```
php artisan make:model Entity -mrc
```
It create a model & migration file & a resource Controller name EntityController.
<P>To create only a resource controller,</P
```
php artisan make:controller EntityController --resource
```
<p>This command will generate a controller at app/Http/Controllers/EntityController.php</p>
<p>In here you have 7 functions <p>1.index(to show all data)</p><p>2.create(to get the blade file creation)</p><p>3.store(to store data into database)</p><p>4.show(to show specific data)</p><p>5.edit(to get the edit blade file )</p><p>6.update(to update that specific data into database)</p><p>7.destroy(to delete data)</p>
Next, you may register a resourceful route to the controller:
```
Route::resource('entities', 'EntityController');
```

You are getting an error because you are trying to assign a `String` where a `TEdit*` is expected.

If you want the `TFileListBox` to display a particular type(s) of file programmably, get rid of the `TFilterComboBox` and use the [`TFileListBox::Mask`](http://docwiki.embarcadero.com/Libraries/en/Vcl.FileCtrl.TFileListBox.Mask) property instead:

> Limits which files are displayed in the file list box.
>
> Set Mask to a regular expression to limit the list box to files that match the mask. The value of the mask is a file name that may include wildcards.

```
String fileType = _D("*.txt");
FileListBox1->Mask = fileType;
```

That said, the file UI components you are using are *ancient*, they were designed during the Windows 3.1 era and should not be using in modern software.

Look at the RTL's [`FindFirst()`](http://docwiki.embarcadero.com/Libraries/en/System.SysUtils.FindFirst) and [`FindNext()`](http://docwiki.embarcadero.com/Libraries/en/System.SysUtils.FindNext) functions to programmably enumerate files with mask filtering. See [Finding a File](http://docwiki.embarcadero.com/RADStudio/en/Finding_a_File) in Embarcadero's documentation for more details.

You need SQL 2008 R2 SP4. This is the last version of SQL Server that supports SQL 2000 databases. Once you restore your database, you will need to back it up again, and then restore in SQL 2017. See [SQL Server 2017 supported versions](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/database-engine/install-windows/supported-version-and-edition-upgrades-2017?view=sql-server-2017)

Unfortunately Microsoft makes it hard getting SQL Server 2008 Developer edition. I suggest you contact Microsoft representatives.

You can download Express [here](https://www.microsoft.com/en-au/download/details.aspx?id=1695) but it will not be able to restore large databases.

Alternatively you can use Azure to create a VM that has SQL 2008 R2 pre-installed. [More info](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/windows/sql/virtual-machines-windows-sql-server-iaas-overview?toc=%2Fazure%2Fvirtual-machines%2Fwindows%2Ftoc.json)

answers.body_markdown:
When you install a package, along with that dependancies of package also get downloaded. If you read this npm [docs on npm-install][1]. It says
`If a package references to another package with a git URL, npm depends on a preinstalled git.` So it will use system installed git to get those dependencies or update the current packages as per the dependencies of the installing package. This will cause to `update your packages as underlying dependencies is also getting updated`.

If you compare now this with yarn, `yarn add` causes ` it places the package on disk. During the next install, this package will be used instead of sending an HTTP request to get the tarball from the registry.`
The desire action you were looking for.

One way to avoid that is that using semantic versioning as intended and specify `"angular5-csv": "1.0.0"` in your package.json for your apps. This way package-lock.json will get definite version of package and npm will not update those packages.



  [1]: https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/npm#dependencies
answers.title: npm install why is everything being executed?

items.body_markdown:
I tried to implement a regex engine using the parser combinators in Haskell.

The idea is that first parse the pattern to build a regex parser, then use the parser to parse the input text.

But my code cannot handle this scenario: if the pattern is something like `a?(a|b).*h+`, then the `h+` after `.*` will never be satisfied since the `.*` part will consume all the inputs.

(Usually the `<|>` is implemented with a `try` func, due to efficiency. But here I don't think this is the case.

Below is my code

```
{-# LANGUAGE LambdaCase #-}
{-# LANGUAGE ScopedTypeVariables #-}

module Matcher where

import           Data.Function (on)
import           Data.Functor (($>))
import           Control.Monad
import           Control.Applicative

newtype Parser a = Parser { runParser :: String -> Maybe (a, String) }

parse :: Parser a -> String -> Maybe a
parse parser inp = case runParser parser inp of
  Just (a, []) -> Just a
  _ -> Nothing

instance Functor Parser where
  fmap t (Parser g) = Parser $ \inp -> fmap (\(a, inp') -> (t a, inp')) (g inp)

instance Applicative Parser where
  pure a = Parser $ \inp -> Just (a, inp)

  (Parser f) <*> (Parser g) = Parser
    $ \inp -> case f inp of
      Nothing        -> Nothing
      Just (t, inp') -> case g inp' of
        Nothing         -> Nothing
        Just (a, inp'') -> Just (t a, inp'')

instance Alternative Parser where
  empty = Parser $ const Nothing

  (Parser f) <|> (Parser g) = Parser
    $ \inp -> case f inp of
      Nothing -> g inp
      Just r  -> Just r

  some p = (:) <$> p <*> (some p <|> pure [])

instance Monad Parser where
  (Parser f) >>= g = Parser
    $ \inp -> case f inp of
      Nothing        -> Nothing
      Just (a, inp') -> runParser (g a) inp'

satisfy p = Parser
  $ \case
    (x:xs)
      | p x -> Just (x, xs)
    _      -> Nothing

char :: Char -> Parser Char
char c = satisfy (== c)

string :: String -> Parser String
string "" = pure ""
string (c:cs) = do
  char c
  string cs
  return (c:cs)

between :: Parser a -> Parser b -> Parser c -> Parser b
between left content right = left *> content <* right

unit :: Parser (Parser String)
unit = (do
          c <- satisfy (`notElem` ['.', '*', '?', '+', '(', ')', '|'])
          return $ fmap (:[]) (char c))
  <|> (char '.' $> fmap (:[]) (satisfy (const True)))
  <|> oneOf

oneOf :: Parser (Parser String)
oneOf = between (char '(') content (char ')')
  where
    content = do
      p1 <- unit
      rest <- many $ char '|' *> unit
      return $ foldr (<|>) p1 rest

oneOrMore :: Parser (Parser String)
oneOrMore = do
  arp <- unit
  char '+'
  return $ fmap concat (some arp)

zeroOrMore :: Parser (Parser String)
zeroOrMore = do
  arp <- unit
  char '*'
  return $ fmap concat (many arp)

zeroOrOne :: Parser (Parser String)
zeroOrOne = do
  arp <- unit
  char '?'
  return $ arp <|> pure ""

reg :: Parser (Parser String)
reg = fmap
  (foldr (liftA2 (++)) (pure ""))
  (some $ zeroOrMore <|> zeroOrOne <|> oneOrMore <|> unit)

createRegParser :: String -> Maybe (Parser String)
createRegParser = parse reg

example = createRegParser "a?(a|b).*h+"
```
items.title: Handling trailing patterns after something like `.*` when building regex engine

If I got your question correctly the query should be defined as follows:

    MATCH (author:Author),(reader:Reader {email:'specific@user.email'}) 
    WHERE NOT (author)-[:REPLIED_TO_COMMENT]->(:ReaderComment)<-[:LEFT_COMMENT]-(reader)
    RETURN DISTINCT author

Explanation of the query:

 1. `MATCH (author:Author),(reader:Reader {email:'specific@user.email'})`  - as you stated you need to query a specifc reader, therefore we are filtering readers by email (just for example), also we are defining `author and reader` "variables" to use later.
 2. `WHERE NOT (author)-[:REPLIED_TO_COMMENT]->(:ReaderComment)<-[:LEFT_COMMENT]-(reader) AND` - you've missed the comment Node Type. We can read this as follows *Where an author didn't reply to any comments left by a specific reader*

answers.body_markdown:
I would proceed as follow:

- first, use a subquery to compare the date of the current record to the minimum date of the series; the difference in days between the dates divided by 7 gives you a first version of the group the record belong to (but for now group numbers are not necessarily consecutive)
- then, use `DENSE_RANK()` in an outer query to reassign group numbers as consecutive numbers:

Query:

    SELECT 
        id,
        obs,
        DENSE_RANK() OVER(ORDER BY gr) grp
    FROM (
        SELECT 
            id,
            obs,
            MIN(obs) OVER(),
            (obs - MIN(obs) OVER())::int/7 + 1 gr
        FROM mytable
    ) x
    ODER BY id

**[Demo on DB Fiddle](https://www.db-fiddle.com/f/smy5EsmYSTeNtDNMTAZhr/5)**;

    | id  | obs                      | grp |
    | --- | ------------------------ | --- |
    | 1   | 2018-01-01T00:00:00.000Z | 1   |
    | 2   | 2018-01-02T00:00:00.000Z | 1   |

answers.body_markdown:
If you want to group things based on a *gap* of seven days, use `lag()` and a cumulative sum to define the groups:

    select t.*,
           count(*) filter (where prev_obs is null or prev_obs < obs - interval '7 day') over (order by obs) as grp
    from (select t.*,
                 lag(obs) over (order by obs) as prev_obs
          from t
         ) t

answers.body_markdown:
Using `re.findall` is **inefficient** for your case, use the following approach with prepared regex pattern and `re.search` feature:

    import re
    
    list_files = ['20190918_TrialBalance_TPBL.txt', '20190918_ManagerBalance_TPCL.txt', '20190918_ManagerBalance_TPCH.txt']
    pat = re.compile(r'trial.*\.txt$', re.I)
    trial_files = [f for f in list_files if pat.search(f)]
    
    print(trial_files)  # ['20190918_TrialBalance_TPBL.txt']


----------
Non-regex approach is also feasible:

    list_files = ['20190918_TrialBalance_TPBL.txt', '20190918_ManagerBalance_TPCL.txt', '20190918_ManagerBalance_TPCH.txt']
    trial_files = []
    for f in list_files:
        f_ = f.lower()
        if 'trial' in f_ and f_.endswith('.txt'):
            trial_files.append(f)
    
    print(trial_files)

answers.body_markdown:
When you convert a list to a string with `str([…])`, Python creates string representations for all elements of the list using `repr()`.

This causes all special characters in strings in the list to be escaped, e.g. `\n` (newline) becomes a literal `\n` (backslash + 'n').

So for this case, you need to check for `\\n\\n` or use a raw string:

    print(myString.count("\\n\\n"))

    print(myString.count(r"\n\n"))

Alternatively, go through every element of the tuples in the list and sum the results:

    sum([stringItem.count('\n\n') for myTuple in myArray for stringItem in myTuple])

answers.body_markdown:
Consider:

    $finalstr =~ s/(.{70})/$1\n/gs;

Expression `(.{70})` captures 70 characters, and then `$1\n` substitutes with the captured part followed by a new line. Modifier `g` makes the search global (each and every match is replaced).

Note: If you string does not contain embedded new lines, you can remove the final `s`.

Example (with 4 characters instead of 70):

    $ perl -we 'my $finalstr = "123456789"; $finalstr =~ s/(.{4})/$1\n/gs; print "$finalstr\n";'
    1234
    5678
    9
    $

---

**Edit**

As commented by [ikegami](https://stackoverflow.com/users/589924/ikegami), an alternative solution would be:

    $finalstr =~ s/.{70}\K/\n/g;

Rationale:

- the `\K` character class indicates that what is left of it should not be suppressed; hence no capturing is needed (this is more efficient than capturing and replacing)

- removing the `s` modifier avoids counting in new lines as characters when matching; thus, if a new line is embedded in the string, the next line will accept 70 characters instead of just the remainder of the previous line.

answers.body_markdown:
You have many errors in your code. First of all, `function Bt()` isn't called. To properly use `addEventListener`, it should be outside of any functions. Use it like this:
`document.addEventListener("click", Bt);`

Also, if calling `chk()` is the only code in your `Bt` function, then you can replace `Bt` with `chk` in your click event listener.
`document.addEventListener("click", chk);`

The next problem is your `chk(n, e, p)` function. If you are going to declare variables in your function, you do not need to fill out the `()` part of the function. So instead, it should look like this: `chk() {}` with the code to be executed inside of `{}`.

Your `if ()` has the same repeating problem. The conditions inside of the parentheses are checked incorrectly. Each condition has to be checked separately. So instead of `(n, e, p < 1 || n, e, p == "" || n, e, p == null || n, e, p == " ")`, it should really be:

`(n < 1 && e < 1 && p < 1 || n == "" && e == "" && p == "" || n == null && e == null && p == null || n == " " && e == " " && p == " ")` Note that I replaced the commas with `&&`, the "and" operator. It checks if the each statement is true, and if at least one isn't true, then it moves to the next block of statements inside of the or operators (`||` ).

Those are the errors I found inside of the SECOND code snippet you gave us. There may be more.

answers.body_markdown:
When you add custom claims to a Firebase Authentication user account, they are not immediately "visible" to the client until their ID token refreshes somehow.  This behavior is [documented][1]:

> After new claims are modified on a user via the Admin SDK, they are
> propagated to an authenticated user on the client side via the ID
> token in the following ways:
> 
> - A user signs in or re-authenticates after the custom claims are modified. The ID token issued as a result will contain the latest
> claims.
> - An existing user session gets its ID token refreshed after an older token expires.
> - An ID token is force refreshed by calling currentUser.getIdToken(true).

So, if you need the client to immediately start using new claims, you should force a refresh using the third bullet point.  Pass `true` to getIdToken.


  [1]: https://firebase.google.com/docs/auth/admin/custom-claims#propagate_custom_claims_to_the_client
answers.title: Firebase currentUser.getIdToken() returns custom token after signInWithCustomToken

answers.body_markdown:
Ultimately, the answer is to not use custom tokens merely to add custom claims for your firebase rules. They are completely different concepts. 

Custom tokens are to implement an unsupported auth provider in addition to those Fb supports - i.e. Google, Microsoft, etc. Custom claims are key/val pairs you can leverage in your security rules and via the claims property on the user.getIdTokenResult() object in the client.


The timeout issue I was debugging was due to trying to re-use the custom token, which doesn't need to be refreshed because it's not what is is for. getIdToken() returns the Id token encoded with any claims that were on the original custom token when it was minted.
answers.title: Firebase currentUser.getIdToken() returns custom token after signInWithCustomToken

method.

answers.body_markdown:
Deployment Manager is currently only offering [support for API methods][1] regarding disks (`compute.alpha.disk`, `compute.beta.disk` and `compute.v1.disk`). Although they support [creating disk from snapshots][2], specifically scheduling should be included in `compute.*.snapshot`, which is not supported.

What you can do instead, is to schedule the snapshots either directly calling the API using the [Client Libraries][3], or using gcloud from another client machine.

Essentially, this particular feature is not yet mapped in Deployment Manager. To determine which APIs are available, you can do:

`gcloud deployment-manager types list`

And check the API documentation for each to see if your particular feature is in one of them.

[1]: https://cloud.google.com/deployment-manager/docs/configuration/supported-resource-types#apis_for_supported_resources
[2]: https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/reference/rest/v1/disks/insert
[3]: https://cloud.google.com/apis/docs/cloud-client-libraries

answers.body_markdown:
`CrossEntropyLoss` requires you to pass in unnormalized logits (output from last `Linear` layer).

If you use `ReLU` as the output from last layer you are only outputting values in the range `[0, inf)`, while neural network tends to go with small values for incorrect labels and high for the correct ones (we may say it's overconfident in it's predictions). Oh, and the one with highest logit value is chosen by `argmax` as correct label.

So it won't definitely work with this line:

    # out = self.relu(out) # this too

Though it should with the `ReLU` before it. Just remember, more nonlinearity isn't always good for the network.

answers.body_markdown:
By calling `DaggerAppComponent.create()` in the `OtherClass` `init{}` block you always creating a new `DaggerAppComponent` with each `OtherClass` instance.
You should cache your component in your application scope to make those `@Singleton` annotation be effective for you.

I think the `Application` class is a good place to do that. You can find a small example [here](https://github.com/overheadhunter/daggerfx).

answers.body_markdown:
I believe one simply interpret the `robot.txt` file with `regex`. The star can usually be interpreted as _anything/everything_.

The User-Agent line `User-agent: *` does not mean you are allowed to scrap everything, it simply means _the following rules apply to all user-agents_. Here are examples of User-Agents

    # Chrome Browser
    Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/76.0.3809.132 Safari/537.36
    # Python requests default
    python-requests/2.19.1

which must comply with the same rules, that is:


 - For example `Disallow: /*?*&*` means you are not _allowed_ to scrap sub-domains of the form 
   
 
        /some_sub_domain?param_name=param_value.

 - Or the line `/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/*/` means the sub-domains of the following form are not allowed to be scraped



        /a/b/c/d/e/f/g/i/


Finally, [here are insightful examples][1] and more on the topic.


  [1]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robots_exclusion_standard#Examples

I am learning Elastic Search, so forgive me for this starter question. 

The scenario is that we have multiple data producer that would send the data to AWS Kinesis firehose which is configured to deliver it to AWS Elastic search.
It is possible that same data is posted to Kinesis firehose by multiple data producers based on different edits happening. 

Since the Kinesis Firehose buffers the request and then delivers in bulk to ES, there is a possibility that the bulk request would have multiple edits of the same document.

How do I ensure that only latest document is processed? 

As a note, all documents have a timestamp field that denote the last modified time for it.

answers.body_markdown:
OK, my original answer was not the answer you wanted. Now that you've clarified:

The `check_password` function does something 'a bit naughty' in casting a `const char*` pointer to an `int*` pointer, but that's OK. It needs at least 20 chars, so that the string can be 'interpreted' as an array of 5 integers.

When you call this function, you need to pass it a character string (of at least 20 chars). In the `main` example you have shown, this string is `argv[1]`, which is the first parameter given to the program *after* its name; so, if you run the program with "checkpw ABCD1234WXYZ5678aaaa" then the ABC... string will be the data passed to the function.

Does this help?
answers.title: This puts out Segmentation fault (core dumped)

answers.body_markdown:
It's because you're passing i as a pointer, and then dereference it. So you will dereference 0x1, an address which you're not supposed to access, and get a SIGSEGV.

Plus, not exactly sure what you're trying to do with this program. The function check password is trying to access an int as an array, that makes no sense.

Edit:
With the complete code it makes much more sense.
What the program is doing is the following:
Takes the first argument (argv[1]), if it's len is 20 (aka if the argument is a 20 characters string), then it will be passed to the function check_password.
Now, here you need a pretty good knowledge of C to understand what is happening.

The pointer to your string, a char const *, is now casted as a pointer to an int.
A character is always one byte. An int is usually 4 bytes. Your string of characters will now be read as an array of int.

Let's take the string "test".
It is encoded in memory in the following way: `0x74(t) 0x73(s) 0x65(e) 0x74(t)`
You will notice it's reversed. That is because most computers nowadays are little endian (ie the biggest bit is read first).
When that string is cast as an int, and access, it will read as an int of value `0x74736574`, aka 1953719668.

The check password is iterating over this array of int 5 times. It will add the first 5 integers it's reading, which means if we take the following password: `abcdefghijklmnopqrst`, the result will be the following:
```
first loop:
res = 0x64636261
second loop:
res += 0x68676665
third loop:
res += 0x72717069
fourth loop:
res += 0x76757473
last loop:
res += 0x7a797877
```

Your goal is to reached the value 0x21DD09EC with the password. One of the many possible answers would be:
`0fwzzzgzabafgccczc9c`

answers.body_markdown:
I found the answer with Honza's help. 
The method "from_dict" is a class method and it resets the search object, thus leaving it without any index to search in and may give more results than expected as it would execute search across all possible indexes.

Instead we just have to mention the index again, something like:
s.from_dict(dict_qry),using(client).index(<index name>)
where client is,
from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch
client = Elasticsearch()

Read about it [here][1] 


  [1]: https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-dsl-py/issues/1244
answers.title: elasticsearch-dsl library in python giving double results when using search.from_dict() method to construct query from dictionary syntax
